speaker: Patient
text: I, uh, know it’s just allergy stuff, but I feel silly asking—my eyes keep leaking already—could I get a whole-year refill so I don’t keep bugging you every few weeks?

speaker: Patient
text: I also, um, wanted to stash an extra bottle in my locker at school because practice runs late and I forget to take it at home sometimes.

speaker: Clinician
text: Sure thing, Alex. Before I click the refill button, a pharmacy alert just pinged my screen saying you reported feeling groggy after a dose last month. Can we unpack that for a sec?

speaker: Clinician
text: I know you’re juggling school, soccer, and living with your grandparents, so I want to be sure the pill isn’t tripping you up during classes or on the field.

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, the day after I doubled up—because I forgot the morning one—I felt kinda spacey and almost nodded off in English. I’m embarrassed because it was just allergies and everyone noticed on the bus ride home.

speaker: Clinician
text: Got it. Loratadine is usually non-drowsy, but stacking two ten-milligram tablets can definitely make you feel foggy. Let’s stick to one daily and set a phone reminder, sound good?

speaker: Clinician
text: About the year-long supply, I can write 90 tablets with three refills; that satisfies insurance and keeps you covered till next spring. We’ll label one bottle for home, one for your locker.

speaker: Clinician
text: Any other meds, supplements, or even those energy drinks the team passes around? I just want to rule out hidden ingredients that might mix badly.

speaker: Patient
text: No, I swear, just water and the occasional sports drink. My grandma keeps asking if I need vitamins, but I haven’t taken anything else. I’m more worried about losing the pills if the locker gets broken into again this year.

speaker: Clinician
text: I hear you. How about we split the supply into smaller blister packs—ten pills each—so even if one goes missing you’re not out a whole bottle? Your grandparents can keep the extras.

speaker: Clinician
text: I’ll also print a quick one-page sheet with the dose, purpose, and side-effect red flags—sleepiness, rash, or racing heart—so teachers or the coach know what’s normal.

speaker: Clinician
text: The pharmacy just asked me to confirm your weight; they flag doses above ten milligrams for kids under thirty kilos. You’re, what, about 140 pounds now, right?

speaker: Clinician
text: If that’s correct, no adjustment needed. I’ll send the e-prescription in the next minute, but before I hit 'submit,' anything else about allergies we haven’t covered?

speaker: Patient
text: Um, maybe just one thing—I get a little wheezy on the first really cold practice in March. Should I keep using my cousin’s old inhaler or is that bad idea?
